data.title: Landmark Chez Artiste to close this week in the latest blow to Denverâ€™s film buffs
data.meta_description: The closure of the Chez Artiste in University Hills comes less than a month after the Landmark Esquire Theatre shuttered.
data.text:
Updated at 2:22 p.m. on Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024

For Denverâ€™s independent film lovers, when it rains, it pours.

At the end of last week, the Landmark Chez Artiste in University Hills announced that it will close its doors for good after Thursday, Aug. 8.

The news comes shortly after the shuttering of the Landmark Esquire Theatre, one of the cityâ€™s bastions for independent and late-night cinema, on July 18.

In a statement from Landmark President Kevin Holloway when he broke the news about the Esquireâ€™s imminent redevelopment, he said: â€œLandmark's renowned Mayan Theatre, Chez Artiste, and The Landmark at Greenwood Village will remain open and continue to serve the area."

However, Chez Artiste employees were notified on Friday of the theaterâ€™s closing. On Saturday, the public was notified with a sign posted to the theatre door, which read:

â€œThe Chez Artiste will be closing permanently. Our last day of operation will be 8/8/2024. It has been our pleasure to serve you!" Please visit us at: Landmark Mayan Theatre and Landmark Greenwood Village.â€

Regulars mourn the Chez Artiste, a longtime home for offbeat films

On Monday of the theatreâ€™s final week, the lobby was crowded with longtime patrons. Some said they were there to pay their respects. Others were there simply because a visit to the Chez Artiste is part of their weekly routine.

Many recognized each other and said their hellos as they stood in line to buy tickets or browse snacks.

Among the friendly hellos were mutters of, â€œItâ€™s such a shame.â€

Robin Kovachy has frequented the Chez Artiste for decades.

â€œThey show interesting, offbeat films,â€ she said, adding that she travels to the theatre from her home in Castle Rock.

Aurora Hunt, an organizer for the Denver Cinema Club, is planning a small farewell for the theatre on Thursday night.

â€œI'm bringing sheet cake and sparkling apple champagne and a notebook so that everyone can wish [the staff] well,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s an opportunity to say goodbye and let them know how grateful we are.â€

She acknowledged that the Chez Artiste doesnâ€™t offer any of the fancy amenities of many other theatres.

â€œThey don't have recliner seats. Their screens are not that big. Nothing about it is that attractive,â€ she said.

People gather there for conversation and community. Thatâ€™s what makes the Chez special.

â€œThey have programmed some kooky nonsense this last year or two, like silent films and obscure things that you've never heard of,â€ Hunt said, â€œAnd just on the strength of who they are, I'll go see anything. It's movie kale â€” I may not love it, but it's good for me. And because there is such elevated discourse at the showings, it's just not like anything else."

Other patrons chimed in online via Reddit.

â€œOver the past 18 months Iâ€™ve been taking my mom, who is struggling with dementia, to every film I think she may like because every person in there is so damn kind to her,â€ wrote user u/Vics. â€œI had no idea they were closing until I saw a sign on the door as we were leaving. I am sad and angry â€“ It seemed obvious that they couldnâ€™t be making money, but for some reason I assumed some of that funding for the arts was earmarked for special places like this and I am angry at myself for that lazy assumption and for my lack of curiosity.â€

Another user by the name of u/Eliese added: â€œOne of the reasons I was so shocked at this news was I figured that if the Chez managed to make it through the pandemic, they were golden.â€

What does this mean for other Landmarks in Denver, like the Mayan?

But research shows that moviegoers arenâ€™t supporting the cinema like they used to.

â€œIn January 2024, attendance was down by 33 percent compared to 2019,â€ an Advan study stated.

In light of Denverâ€™s recent Landmark theatre closures, local cinephiles fear for the Mayan Theatre on Broadway.

However, the Art Deco Mayan Revival-style building was declared a historic landmark in 1984. This protects it from major redevelopment and may help that Landmark location survive.

â€œA couple years ago a new president [Holloway] was installed for Landmark who came from the big chain theaters,â€ said Redditor u/smertai, a former Mayan Theatre employee. â€œ(But) the big movies don't pull numbers at all I'm told.â€

From what patrons had to say, thatâ€™s not why they go to Landmark theatres. They go for the screenings that they canâ€™t find elsewhere â€” and they go for the community.

Chez Artiste employees encourage movie lovers who want to speak their minds to contact [email protected].
